text: Da is a consonant of Indic abugidas. In modern Indic scripts, Da is derived from the early "Ashoka" Brahmi letter ng after having gone through the Gupta letter 13px. ==Āryabhaṭa numeration== Aryabhata used Devanagari letters for numbers, very similar to the Greek numerals, even after the invention of Indian numerals. The values of the different forms of द are: *द = 18 (१८) *दि = 1,800 (१ ८००) *दु = 180,000 (१ ८० ०००) *दृ = 18,000,000 (१ ८० ०० ०००) *दॢ = 18 (१८×१०८) *दे = 18 (१८×१०१०) *दै = 18 (१८×१०१२) *दो = 18 (१८×१०१४) *दौ = 18 (१८×१०१६) ==Historic Da== There are three different general early historic scripts - Brahmi and its variants, Kharoṣṭhī, and Tocharian, the so-called slanting Brahmi. Da as found in standard Brahmi, Da was a simple geometric shape, with variations toward more flowing forms by the Gupta Da. The Tocharian Da Da did not have an alterante Fremdzeichen form. The third form of da, in Kharoshthi (Da) was probably derived from Aramaic separately from the Brahmi letter. ===Brahmi Da=== The Brahmi letter Da, Da, is probably derived from the altered Aramaic Dalet 13px, and is thus related to the modern Latin D and Greek Delta. Several identifiable styles of writing the Brahmi Da can be found, most associated with a specific set of inscriptions from an artifact or diverse records from an historic period.Evolutionary chart, Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal Vol 7, 1838 As the earliest and most geometric style of Brahmi, the letters found on the Edicts of Ashoka and other records from around that time are normally the reference form for Brahmi letters, with vowel marks not attested until later forms of Brahmi back-formed to match the geometric writing style. {|class="wikitable" |+Brahmi Da historic forms |- !Ashoka (3rd-1st c. BCE) !! Girnar (~150 BCE) !! Kushana (~150-250 CE) !! Gujarat (~250 CE) !! Gupta (~350 CE) |- | 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px |} ===Tocharian Da=== The Tocharian letter Da is derived from the Brahmi Da, but does not have an alternate Fremdzeichen form. {|class="wikitable" |+Tocharian Da with vowel marks |- ! Da !! Dā !! Di !! Dī !! Du !! Dū !! Dr !! Dr̄ !! De !! Dai !! Do !! Dau !! Dä |- | 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px |} ===Kharoṣṭhī Da=== The Kharoṣṭhī letter Da is generally accepted as being derived from the altered Aramaic Dalet 13px, and is thus related to D and Delta, in addition to the Brahmi Da. ==Devanagari Da== Da (द) is a consonant of the Devanagari abugida. It ultimately arose from the Brahmi letter ka, after having gone through the Gupta letter 13px. Letters that derive from it are the Gujarati letter દ, and the Modi letter 𑘟. ===Devanagari-using Languages=== In all languages, द is pronounced as or when appropriate. Like all Indic scripts, Devanagari uses vowel marks attached to the base consonant to override the inherent /ə/ vowel: {|class="wikitable" |+ Devanagari द with vowel marks |- ! Da !! Dā !! Di !! Dī !! Du !! Dū !! Dr !! Dr̄ !! Dl !! Dl̄ !! De !! Dai !! Do !! Dau !! D |-style="font-size: 150%;" |द |दा |दि |दी |दु |दू |दृ |दॄ |दॢ |दॣ |दे |दै |दो |दौ |द् |} ===Conjuncts with द=== Devanagari exhibits conjunct ligatures, as is common in Indic scripts. In modern Devanagari texts, most conjuncts are formed by reducing the letter shape to fit tightly to the following letter, usually by dropping a character's vertical stem, sometimes referred to as a "half form". Some conjunct clusters are always represented by a true ligature, instead of a shape that can be broken into constituent independent letters. Vertically stacked conjuncts are ubiquitous in older texts, while only a few are still used routinely in modern Devanagari texts. D however, does not have a vertical stem to drop for making a half form, and either forms a stacked conjunct/ligature, or uses its full form with Virama. The use of ligatures and vertical conjuncts may vary across languages using the Devanagari script, with Marathi in particular preferring the use of half forms where texts in other languages would show ligatures and vertical stacks. ====Ligature conjuncts of द==== True ligatures are quite rare in Indic scripts. The most common ligated conjuncts in Devanagari are in the form of a slight mutation to fit in context or as a consistent variant form appended to the adjacent characters. Those variants include Na and the Repha and Rakar forms of Ra. Nepali and Marathi texts use the "eyelash" Ra half form Ra for an initial "R" instead of repha. * र্ (r) + द (da) gives us the ligature rda: 100px * द্ (d) + न (na) gives us the ligature dna: 100px * द্ (d) + र (ra) gives us the ligature dra: 100px * द্ (d) + द (da) gives us the ligature dda: 100px * द্ (d) + द্ (d) + र (ra) gives us the ligature ddra: 100px * द্ (d) + द্ (d) + य (ya) gives us the ligature ddya: 100px * द্ (d) + ध (dʱa) gives us the ligature ddʱa: 100px * द্ (d) + ध্ (dʱ) + म (ma) gives us the ligature ddʱma: 100px * द্ (d) + ध্ (dʱ) + व (va) gives us the ligature ddʱva: 100px * न্ (n) + द্ (d) + ध (dʱa) gives us the ligature nddʱa: 100px * र্ (r) + द্ (d) + ध (dʱa) gives us the ligature rddʱa: 100px * द্ (d) + य (ya) gives us the ligature dya: 100px ====Stacked conjuncts of द==== Vertically stacked ligatures are the most common conjunct forms found in Devanagari text. Although the constituent characters may need to be stretched and moved slightly in order to stack neatly, stacked conjuncts can be broken down into recognizable base letters, or a letter and an otherwise standard ligature. * छ্ (cʰ) + द (da) gives us the ligature cʰda: 100px * द্ (d) + ब (ba) gives us the ligature dba: 100px * द্ (d) + भ (bʰa) gives us the ligature dbʰa: 100px * द্ (d) + ब্ (b) + र (ra) gives us the ligature dbra: 100px * द্ (d) + च (ca) gives us the ligature dca: 100px * द্ (d) + छ (cʰa) gives us the ligature dcʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + द (da) gives us the ligature ḍda: 100px * द্ (d) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature dḍa: 100px * द্ (d) + ढ (ḍʱa) gives us the ligature dḍʱa: 100px * ढ্ (ḍʱ) + द (da) gives us the ligature ḍʱda: 100px * द্ (d) + ग (ga) gives us the ligature dga: 100px * द্ (d) + घ (ɡʱa) gives us the ligature dɡʱa: 100px * द্ (d) + ग্ (g) + र (ra) gives us the ligature dgra: 100px * द্ (d) + ह (ha) gives us the ligature dha: 100px * द্ (d) + ज (ja) gives us the ligature dja: 100px * द্ (d) + झ (jʰa) gives us the ligature djʰa: 100px * द্ (d) + ज্ (j) + ञ (ña) gives us the ligature djña: 100px * द্ (d) + क (ka) gives us the ligature dka: 100px * द্ (d) + ख (kʰa) gives us the ligature dkʰa: 100px * द্ (d) + क্ (k) + ष (ṣa) gives us the ligature dkṣa: 100px * द্ (d) + ल (la) gives us the ligature dla: 100px * द্ (d) + ळ (ḷa) gives us the ligature dḷa: 100px * द্ (d) + म (ma) gives us the ligature dma: 100px * द্ (d) + ङ (ŋa) gives us the ligature dŋa: 100px * द্ (d) + ण (ṇa) gives us the ligature dṇa: 100px * द্ (d) + ञ (ña) gives us the ligature dña: 100px * द্ (d) + प (pa) gives us the ligature dpa: 100px * द্ (d) + फ (pʰa) gives us the ligature dpʰa: 100px * द্ (d) + स (sa) gives us the ligature dsa: 100px * द্ (d) + श (ʃa) gives us the ligature dʃa: 100px * द্ (d) + ष (ṣa) gives us the ligature dṣa: 100px * द্ (d) + त (ta) gives us the ligature dta: 100px * द্ (d) + थ (tʰa) gives us the ligature dtʰa: 100px * द্ (d) + ट (ṭa) gives us the ligature dṭa: 100px * द্ (d) + ठ (ṭʰa) gives us the ligature dṭʰa: 100px * द্ (d) + व (va) gives us the ligature dva: 100px * द্ (d) + व্ (v) + य (ya) gives us the ligature dvya: 100px * ङ্ (ŋ) + द (da) gives us the ligature ŋda: 100px * र্ (r) + द্ (d) + व (va) gives us the ligature rdva: 100px * ट্ (ṭ) + द (da) gives us the ligature ṭda: 100px * ठ্ (ṭʰ) + द (da) gives us the ligature ṭʰda: 100px ==Bengali Da== The Bengali script দ is derived from the Siddhaṃ 13px, and is marked by a similar horizontal head line, but less geometric shape, than its Devanagari counterpart, द. The inherent vowel of Bengali consonant letters is /ɔ/, so the bare letter দ will sometimes be transliterated as "do" instead of "da". Adding okar, the "o" vowel mark, gives a reading of /d̪o/. Like all Indic consonants, দ can be modified by marks to indicate another (or no) vowel than its inherent "a". {|class="wikitable" |+ Bengali দ with vowel marks |- ! da !! dā !! di !! dī !! du !! dū !! dr !! dr̄ !! de !! dai !! do !! dau !! d |-style="font-size: 150%;" |দ |দা |দি |দী |দু |দূ |দৃ |দৄ |দে |দৈ |দো |দৌ |দ্ |} ===দ in Bengali- using languages=== দ is used as a basic consonant character in all of the major Bengali script orthographies, including Bengali and Assamese. ===Conjuncts with দ=== Bengali দ exhibits conjunct ligatures, as is common in Indic scripts, with a tendency towards stacked ligatures. * ব্ (b) + দ (da) gives us the ligature bda: 100px * দ্ (d) + ভ (bʰa) gives us the ligature dbʰa: 100px * দ্ (d) + ভ্ (bʰ) + র (ra) gives us the ligature dbʰra, with the ra phala suffix: 100px * দ্ (d) + দ (da) gives us the ligature dda: 100px * দ্ (d) + ধ (dʱa) gives us the ligature ddʱa: 100px * দ্ (d) + দ্ (d) + ব (va) gives us the ligature ddva, with the va phala suffix: 100px * দ্ (d) + গ (ga) gives us the ligature dga: 100px * দ্ (d) + ঘ (ɡʱa) gives us the ligature dɡʱa: 100px * দ্ (d) + ম (ma) gives us the ligature dma: 100px * দ্ (d) + র (ra) gives us the ligature dra, with the ra phala suffix: 100px * দ্ (d) + র্ (r) + য (ya) gives us the ligature drya, with the ra phala and ya phala suffixes 100px * দ্ (d) + ব (va) gives us the ligature dva, with the va phala suffix: 100px * দ্ (d) + য (ya) gives us the ligature dya, with the ya phala suffix: 100px * ন্ (n) + দ (da) gives us the ligature nda: 100px * ন্ (n) + দ্ (d) + র (ra) gives us the ligature ndra, with the ra phala suffix: 100px * ন্ (n) + দ্ (d) + ব (va) gives us the ligature ndva, with the va phala suffix: 100px * ন্ (n) + দ্ (d) + য (ya) gives us the ligature ndya, with the ya phala suffix: 100px * র্ (r) + দ (da) gives us the ligature rda, with the repha prefix: 100px * র্ (r) + দ্ (d) + র (ra) gives us the ligature rdra, with the repha prefix and ra phala suffix: 100px * র্ (r) + দ্ (d) + ব (va) gives us the ligature rdva, with the repha prefix and va phala suffix: 100px ==Javanese Da== ==References== Category:Indic letters
title: Da (Indic)
